comments.commentBody: Thank you, Thomas.

Anybody remember Bristol Palin? Track? What an example that family gives us all of self-control, don't they?!

Let's have universal easy access to cheap/free birth control, puleeze!

In the long term a reduction in the population growth rate would certainly be a benefit. But it's not going to do anything to solve the immediate problem of criminality facing families like those described in the article.

It seems in many countries that the population growth rate reductions FOLLOW from increased education and economic opportunity. By focusing FIRST on population growth rates I believe you are putting the cart before the horse. By all means if we are going to try to help in some way, then one of those ways should be to support better family planning. But that must be part of a package that includes improved education, business development, increased transparency in government and its related reduction in institutionalized corruption, as well as assistance with policing.

It would also be helpful if Americans stopped buying illegal drugs originating from Central America. American drug users are currently financing a large part of this criminality.
Wonder how many illegal immigrants Kristoff  is supporting in the neighborhood where he lives?  I bet you NONE.

You had me until you said the US needs a one child policy. The US birth rate cannot sustain the nation's need for workers. The problem is the same in Europe. In Germany the replacement rate for those who die is in the negative area. In fact Muslims are already proclaiming their belief that in one generation they will replace Germany's ethnic participation because of its birth rate of less than one child per family unit with their 6-10 child rate. Latin Americans are doing the same to the US although it isn't an ideological position.

This is irresponsible reporting by a sanctimonious Nicholas Kristof.

The real crime is having large families in an overpopulated world. Honduras has a population growth rate of 2%, which is unsustainable in the long run.

We don't know exactly what happens in Honduras, but when the growth rate is this high, the ultimate results are always gruesome.

In some cases it is outright starvation. More commonly, high birth rates lead to social disorder, the spreading of crime, disintegration of the family, and the building up of ghettos.

It is a human rights abuse for countries like Honduras to keep their people from having access to safe birth control, and to abortions when those are necessary to limit family size.

And liberals like Kristof are also guilty of human rights abuse when they fail to note the connection between high birth rates and devastating drops in living standards.

One thing is certain. The crimes of the officials in Honduras who prevent the maintenance of small families to protect the planet should NOT be visited upon Americans by Obama's illegal acts of providing amnesty for an unlimited stream of illegal immigrants.

We need to control our borders and maintain respect for American laws. At the same time we need to recognize the crimes of governments like those in Latin America which prevent family planning, and perpetuate poverty by preventing birth control and abortion.

America needs a one child policy. So does Latin America.

If he becomes president, he could announce the National Alert Level in his mane. Except for gala state dinner when it has to be pure gold. What better way to keep the citizenry alert?

Whoever will be the next president, one thing is for sure: it is going to be a fake blond.

For Trump, it is a strategic defense shield: just as his opponent is trying to counter his pointless arguments, the thoughts are diverted by the bright orange blob.

Since you have first hand experience I would be interested to know more. What is your perception of corruption within the political system?

Solutions to pervasive crime are often impeded by institutional corruption. Would you say that the government, police/military needs to be "cleaned up" first or would you say that it would successfully fight crime if it had more means available?

Is the extortion a rural phenomenon? Is it specific to a certain region?

What about educational opportunities for children? How would you characterize them?

Thanks.

If our legislature could be forward thinking, and accept years of recommendations to promote more education abroad, there would be an incredibly high yield on investment. Emigration would decline, and yes...tourism would increase as many Americans prefer travel to locations where the natives speak English.

'...the streets are bursting is a large, heartening population of school children...'

Perhaps not reproducing without any thought of how to support the children would help reduce poverty?

Nah, that would never work.

I travel to and live part-time en western El Salvador; I speak/read/write Spanish well. I do not live among The "globalist tribe" that Kristoff wrote about recently, but among country town young and their families, with average earnings of about $400 per month ($500 is the salary advertised for English)
El Salvador and it's neighbors are beautiful places and the Salvadorans are kind, hardworking, respect success, and generally like the US (probably due to lack of contact as their is literally no tourism, despite having clean, empty Pacific beaches, beautiful countryside, and nice, small colonial towns sprinkled about the coffee covered volcanic mountains- due to its reputation for gang violence). There are few English speakers.
I've spent the equivalent of a year there since 2011, traveling alone, or with Salvadorans on intercity buses, on foot and in private or rental cars, and have yet to be even threatened in El Salvador, though as one of the few foreigners out in a he country, tall and blue-eyed, and an accented Spanish, I stand out.
Yes, there is violence, as I read in the local papers. Most do not want to leave but the extortion and lack a of opportunity is the problem. The people I know in the western towns are not leaving and the streets are bursting is a large, heartening population of school children.
Once you he gangs are extirpated, and the that's what it will take, and some opportunity, tourism will begin, for better or worse. This is a solvable problem.

Why do we have to depend on the game where we explore? The process to determine the sites of explorations is important. Talking with their friends and consult adults, children can increase the pleasure of explorations and exclude the risk of accidents. If you choose the site for exploration by using the game, it is not a true exploration, just a fake one.

Book review WSJ Thursday, July 14, 2016

Bookshelf by Morton Kondracke
Scoring A Presidency
Bush
By Jean Edward Smith

"Jean Edward Smith- - author of studies of presidents as varied as Grant, FDR, and Eisenhower-has written a withering portrait of George W. Bush. it's overly harsh in many respects, yet Mr. Smith presents a strong case that, although it may be debatable whether Mr. Bush was Americas worst president, his " decision to invade Iraq s easily the worst foreign policy decision ever made by an American president."

Further on he writes, "Federal debt held by the public ballooned to 52.3 of the GDP in 2009 from 31.4 in 2001..."

That the WSJ would review this book shows what low esteem even one of the most conservative GOP publications think ow W's presidency. And you defend him, not from the facts, but from an emotional opinion. It is obvious to everyone who reads your comments, that you are an intransigent true believer in GOP fairy tales.
Not as easy as it sounds with gerrymandered districts favoring Republicans.

It wasn't and isn't possible to design a health care system from scratch in the US. So, any feasible approach to reform must be incremental and must compromise among competing interests.

If, for political reasons, in states controlled by Republicans, many more go uninsured, I strongly recommend that they vote for new leaders.

Mini-apartments are only an answer for some young singles and perhaps some retirees. IMHO not enough to make a significant dent. Driverless cars may make more of a dent in the future (possibly eliminating a lot of parking and some garage space (here in CA as much garage space is probably used for storage as for cars), but I suspect that's still a ways out and the effect may be more limited than hoped.

One note is that although you're right about expanding urban areas giving relief to land prices, there's a limit to that. The San Francisco Bay Area is probably the best example. We several decades ago pretty much hit the limit of tolerably convenient buildable land (because of the bay and mountains), and real estate prices have exploded, with still no end in sight. A quick back of napkin calculation on my part yields more than 4% per year increase from 1976 until now deducting inflation, significantly better even than GDP.
Ha! Anyone else wonder if maw Ginsberg has an opinion of Erdogan that she would like to share?

He wasn't out of the country, but in Marmaris, a resort area where he was vacationing. Is that a crime?

Funny how now that it blew up on their faces, those behind the coup are trying to spread conspiracy theories about Erdogan engineering the coup.

Erdogan is the Trump of Turkey trying to reinstitute independence.
We already know.

"... too quickly ..."

How long should an attempted coup last to "smell right"?

"And Erdogan was conveniently out of the country ..."

Would you stage a coup when the boss is in town or out of town?
Remember the Barhain uprising and the Saudi invasion? Yeah, most American don't because it is one article on NYTimes. All the news deemed fit to print.

Why do so many of us (myself included) get the impression that the New York Times -- and the rest of the US news media -- are not telling us everything they know here? Other commenters have already noted the dissonance between the photos and the text, and have posited theories ranging from "Reichstag Fire" to "Bay of Pigs." Wouldn't it be better for the Obama administration and its stenographers to simply level with the American people? Or do you fear, like Jack Nicholson's Col. Jessup in "A Few Good Men" that the Great Unwashed just can't handle the truth?

Gulans been gone for 14 years. I seriously doubt he had anything to do with this so called coup attempt. This reeks of a set up. It all worked out so well for Erdogan and reminds one of the 1933 bombing of the Reichstag which provided Hitler with the ability to take control of the gov't completely, purging anyone who had stood against him. That said, I would agree that the US has an abysmal history of supporting military coups and I'm glad we did not this time, in spite of the fact that I believe the whole thing was orchestrated by Erdogan.
To keep them out of your reach, out sourcing national security.

Lots of people blame president Erdogan changing the secular democratic country to a Islamic country.  It caused the coup.  Is that a good reason to have a military coup?  How about Syria?  She is also a secular democratic country but we support the rebels.  Why?  It doesn't make sense.  Who is the good guy & who is the bad guy?  Politics is always intriguing & confusing.
It's not too hard to figure out who promulgated this.  Frankly, I can understand their feelings.  However, I don't see us extraditing our Secretary of State.

Muslim nations such as Turkey and Syria need to have western world shadow governments in the background to guide them during their transistion into Democracy. Until muslim majority nations loosen up and have less emphasis on religion in their societies, nothing will change. Muslims are too serious about religion and should practice tolerance of other religions and view points. It's a sign that they don't think their religion is strong enough to stand on its own merits if they cannot operate as Democracies do, with lots of religious beliefs and atheism. The kids need to have more fun and play peaceful happy games instead of learning to hate other religions and the western world. Religion is only one aspect of life.
It is horrible. Our leaders have BLOOD on their hands. :/
The Military was Ataturk!
Rolls my eyes. Erdogan is responsible for this... Those boys don't look old enough to stage anything. Our leaders hands are FULL of blood.

It HAD to be staged.. Come on... it was over in 24 hours.. and look at the soldiers. Just kids taking orders... now being beaten my thugs. Erdogan the biggest one of all. And knocking on the door of Europe.

He has imprisoned more journalists than ANY other country in the world including China. I have no idea if the coup was,real and I'm glad my country supported a democratically elected gov't but you're living in a dream world if you think those arrested won't either be executed or tortured.

Well from what I heard from people in the streets in Cairo last fall not everyone thought the MB was a great democratic choice. Three people, a street hustler, a driver and a teacher all made a point of bringing up the fact they felt betrayed by Obama because he supported the MB. And where have so many of them gone since Egypt threw them out of power? Turkey. From what I can tell Turkey has really changed from what it was when I was there 8 years ago. It's doesn't appear to be the tolerant place/ European city it was. Something is changing it. Not sure for the better.
